Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then take great care in drawing them out, and do not let anything remain in the limb with your force
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If indeed something causes resistance in the limb from humors, and there is no fear of incision, or an error: then incise those humors and tissues, if they are there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If indeed the limb is not prepared for the extraction of the bone at that hour, then place upon it that which will cause it to decay: and draw it out when it has decayed from the surrounding bones of flesh and humors.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep the limb so that it does not become consolidated.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision be as small as you made it in your operation
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	And if you put on it, if necessary, a bandage soaked in sulfur with oil: or a bandage soaked in Egyptian unguent or any other unguents of your choice.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when they have decayed indeed these humors, and are separated from the bones, the wound will be soothed, and the attraction of them will be removed
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If indeed there is a large bone, such as the thigh bone or the hip bone, and those like these, which are corrupted from it, is a great part: then take away that part in its last degree, until the black spot and the corruption are removed
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the limb.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If indeed that which is in it corrupted is a great part, and the corruption has reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to cut through it and open it up to the depth where the corruption exists: then take care of it until it is consolidated
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you this, that which has happened to me in my leg: that you may take it as an example and aid in your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age had pain in his leg, because something had moved within his body towards the thigh, and as a result there was swelling: there was no external cause of the pain
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	It has been prolonged thus with the error of the physicians until the swelling opened, and many materials came out together with it
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after that his cure was delayed until his leg was bandaged, and many holes were made in it: from which pus and moisture of the body were emitted
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	And they treated him for two years with various physicians, but there was no skill in their art, until I saw him and opened his leg, and the matters which were coming out of his holes in great quantity: even all the men in the place fainted, and his color was pale yellow
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	Then they attempted to open one of his holes, and they reached the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	And I saw that all his holes were communicating with each other throughout the whole thigh
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I treated him accordingly, and I cauterized one of his holes until I saw a piece of bone: and I found it corrupted: for it was rotten, discoloured, putrefying, and perforated, until it had penetrated even to the marrow
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw what had been detected by me, and prepared from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I thought that there was no other corruption in the bone except that which I had cut away, so I cauterized and excised it.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	I will eradicate it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I shall institute the restoration of the wound together with the physicians in a spacious place for a long period.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated yet
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried, and I found upon the second examination: there is a continued corruption with the bone: and I saw that there was also corruption from that corruption itself.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	I then attempted to restore it
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored yet
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found therefore upon it again, and I did not cease to cut the bone piecemeal, and to try to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut from the bone about the space of one palm, and I extracted that with the marrow together
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed: and no further operation was necessary for this purpose, except for the disposition of the weakness of the patient, and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him, because he was perishing in every hour from excessive vomiting of bad evacuations
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was healed completely: and was born in the place of the broken bone, and was made well the disposition of his body, and recovered his strength: and was discharged from his bed: and did not cause him any pain in walking ever afterwards
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If, however, the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to bind it up as follows: take a ligament and bind the fractured bone at its extremity: and command someone to extend it upwards: and put another ligament of greater thickness than the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it over the flesh which is above the bone: and extend its extremity, so that you pull the meat downwards: and you will know that the meat is properly placed where you wish to cut it, so that it does not damage the meat
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone in the center: for when you do this, it will not prevent the marrow from separating the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	The incision should be made above the corrupted part without damaging the surrounding area of the bone.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and does not protrude, the corrupted part must be continued with the sound portion: and the corruption is in the middle or the part itself: then remove the flesh from all sides entirely
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards, saw from the first part where the corruption is until the incision is continued from the other side: and let the incision be as far from the corruption as possible, as we have said before.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is in the joint, saw through the corrupted joint and saw the bone where the incision continues from the other side
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is no wisdom in it except abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand or in the sole of the foot: then matters are difficult there
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	It is necessary to inquire how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape away the bone and clean it as much as possible according to any way that is possible for you: and with whatever ingenuity you can manage, so that it does not cause harm to the vein or nerve
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	You know that the saws and chisels for cutting this bone are many, according to the position of the bones, their preparation, their size, their shape, their weight, their fineness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Wherever necessary, one must prepare an instrument suitable for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	You also know that these operations are greater than the kind of instrument which is suitable for them, when you have long studies about them
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the modes of this art is a testimony of the modes of illness: for then you will find that everything which is suitable for one infirmity is not suitable for another
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	I am firm in the last of this chapter concerning the number of instruments, which I have placed as examples of those which you should take into consideration, and the trial which you will experience with others.
Forma Serrae.	Serra form.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Form of the other Serra
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of the third Serra
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of the fourth Serra
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of Serra is made, when it is placed in the center
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Its arch is made of iron, its point from steel: and its handle from boxwood, and it is made pyramidally in the center
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Form of Rasassa of the united.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Its head is like the head of the clavus stellatus: and its points are like the points of the elishate.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	It is not suitable, except when it is rubbed with it, because of the fracture of the head, or because of the great swelling and size of the bone
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Form of the greater Rasassa
Forma medii Rasorii.	Form of the middle Rasassa
Forma Rasorii lati.	Form of the narrow Rasassa
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Form of the concaved Rasassa
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The shape of the other incision is finer.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape of the other incision is curved at its extremities
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape of the other incision is small and fine
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape of the other incision is like that of a broken bone
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape of the other incision is great
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is like a radio and the extremities are like a saw: it appears in many places because of the reason for the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of the other incision is suitable for the reason for which it has been made through the bones
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremities are triangular, and the extremities are acute
Fit ex Indi.	It is like an Indian
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And it should be like this for all incisions, and for the sutures and the saws
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	As for the incision of the extremities, and the suture of the bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy, either by an external cause, or an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When you have treated the cause of this corruption with medical means, and the cure has not occurred: and if you do not cut away the corruption of the limb which does not recover: then you must cut away that limb until the corruption has ceased, so that the patient may be saved from death or from the greater defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this is that the limb is blackened, until it is burned: or it becomes putrid after blackness: until that putridity is cut away from the limb itself, and from the whole body
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Properly therefore when the incision has been made, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from a blow which has struck some of the veins: such as a scorpion of the sea, and vipers, and spiders, and things of that kind.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption is at the extremity of the finger, then incise the finger and not leave space for the corruption, but proceed until the other hand is reached
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the palm, then incise from the root of the bone, and not leave space for the corruption, until it reaches the wrist bone
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it comes to this, then incise the arm at the elbow in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however the corruption has passed, and you see it surrounding the elbow: then in that is the cause of the malady.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer besides this from the treatment, is the quantity of the vomit.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And do the same with the foot, when the corruption comes to the finger, then incise it at one of the joints: and if it happens at the heel, then incise the whole foot
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If however it reaches the knee, then incise the leg at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	What if the corruption has gone beyond the knee? Then it is not in that it is incurable, except for amputation, and to leave the patient dead.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to incisions the limb, or to save it, is as follows: to string the ligament in the lower part, which one you wish to cut: and to string the ligament above in the place of the other
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend one minister ligament downwards: and extend the other minister ligament upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between two ligaments, with the edge of a spatula, until the whole flesh is torn away
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it may occur, or it may return.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	Then it must be placed from all parts of the bandage around the limb, and must not touch the healthy area: and it must be added to the patient's pain, and the swelling must be cooled.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, blood flows inwards during the operation, then cauterize the place quickly: or place above it some powder that will absorb the blood.</start_of_turn>
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medicine, until it is complete.</start_of_turn>
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a bandage that is suitable for it, and care for it, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I say that this happened to me in my foot, this is what happened to me.</start_of_turn
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because in my foot there was a black spot, with a swelling which assimilated the heat of fire: and the corruption first happened in my finger, until it reached the whole foot.</start_of_turn
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore I removed the person from himself, after I had cut away the corruption from the limb with my shears, because of the pain, and the swelling: and I put it on the joint, and it healed.</start_of_turn
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption happened to him in the nail of his middle finger.</start_of_turn
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to cure the swelling with the things which I put on his hand from the physicians after the purification of his body: and the swelling did not disappear, but it increased in another finger: until the corruption reached the hand.</start_of_turn
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to cut off his hand: and I did not do that, hoping for the return of the swelling: and I was also afraid of the death of his hand.</start_of_turn
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Wherever there was a wound on a man, it was above the case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	When I had left him, he returned to his land: and he came to me because he had been nearby, and he wounded his whole hand: and he was healed.</start_of_turn>
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not relate this story except in order to help with regard to that which falls from the nature of this ailment: and in order to show what is signified, and according to how it is done.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Concerning the care of bones, and the quality of blistering with the physicians.</start_of_turn
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When there is swelling in some limb with carbuncle, and the swelling is prolonged until collection of pus has taken place: then it is broken open, or pierced, and the pus which is in it is driven out, and the cavity which remains is like a wound: and the skin which is over it is like a thin membrane which has been stripped off: and it does not reach its final corruption, neither does it reach the bone, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it is called a sinus, and not a fistula, truly; but if the space of the former is prolonged until corruption affects some part of the limb, then it is called a fistula, or swelling.</start_of_turn>
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is that you cut away the whole skin as it turns black: and especially when it is thinned out, and made like a membrane: and trust that it will not stick to the place, because of its corruption.</start_of_turn
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere, and that no corruption will result from this: and if there is thick blood in the skin, then treat it with blistering: and consider it as a sinus.</start_of_turn
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	If it be great, and the pus which proceeds from it is foetid of odor: then clisterize it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and gum, equal parts, gathered in a vessel: and boil them over fire, until the medicine turns red: and then add honey to it.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and clisterize it with wine: and tie up its orifice, and give the medicine in it to the quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw out its contents with pressure: do this every day, until the sinus is healed, and the stench is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is clistered with vinegar and water, when it is not present this medicine: then take charcoal of wood or charcoal of beech: and cast it on the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then keep the water still, and clisterize with it, until you are confident that the sinus is healed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, neither vinegar and water: then clisterize it with water and honey, to which something of ground mastic has been added
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clisterize it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to heal and cleanse: and the wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of styptic and drying in it.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this often, and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has departed: then clisterize it with something that makes meat grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take from alum of diaphanicon: and dissolve it with rose oil and wine styptic: or clisterize it with some medicine, and anoint with others, of whose properties are written in the treatise on unguents.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the opening of the sinus is strict, so that a cannula will not pass through it: then widen it with a needle; or place within it a pledget of lint in Egyptian unguent, or in basilicon unguent, until it is widened.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	Similarly, if the opening is also large, then gather its lips together with sutures; and let out from it as much as enters the bladder without adding anything.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if pus comes from the opening, let it be raised upwards: then dry it in the lower part which is in it, so that it comes out from there downwards: for pus, when it is collected in the depth of the sinus, hinders the generation of flesh in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible to dry the sinus round about downwards, then try to prepare the limb with the preparation which lets out pus with ease according to the way it is prepared for you
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try that no pus remains in it at all: and take solidifying medicines which are placed over the sign, suitable for this purpose
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend ease over the edge of the wound.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the size of the dressing be such as to communicate with the whole sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then pierce with forceps directly at the opening of the sinus, widening the opening of the sinus with a needle.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the sponges above the other dressing, according to the quantity of the hole: and place it over itself in a long position away from the opening of the sinus, so as to relieve the discharge of pus from it: and do not put on a large dressing, except after a few days or until one has healed one
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is over the opening of the sinus should move in every hour, so that what is gathered in it from the pus may go out: and you will know whether it is much or little, or digested or undigested
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And thus again consider the location of the sinus itself, whether the master of the limb feels pain there, or whether there is no pain there, and whether there is swelling there, or whether there is no swelling there.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When you have thus advanced your remedy in this way, and you have dried the material which proceeds from the opening of the sinus, then you will know whether the sinus is firmly adhered, or approaches adherence: then you must remove it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you have removed the ulcer, then change the bandage, and renew the unguentum.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If, however, it proceeds from the sinus beyond a long space or a subtle ulcer, then do not despair of its adherence, for its healing approaches, because there are men who are slow in the generation of flesh in their ulcers, and there are those who act contrariwise to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If, however, it proceeds from the sinus after many days with undigested pus, then you know that the sinus is not adhered
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If thus the adherence of the sinus is delayed and its condition is prolonged: then add in the treatment of the physician, truly let the physicians do what they will, that there be moisture in their medications and dryness in their moisture: like gypsum, when added in excess produces abundance of moisture.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last method of treatment, that is, take gypsum and dissolve it with rosewater, and apply it over the old liquid in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then keep it together with this, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does the same thing to this action as when there is no gypsum present, honey, when you boil it, until it has thickened, and you use it with this
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloes, and olibanum: mix them all together, and grind them over honey while it is still over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then line above the belly, and string the belly above the hip: and line with honey which you boiled, until it is thickened: and powder above the belly, and put above the belly the belly-bag, and string it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when it is administered in this belly-bag, long parsley, and roots of lily of the valley, and is lily: and barley of herbs, and centaury
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use either singly or compounded, these, and the sponges themselves: and powder above the honey which I have told you of, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If, however, the matter of the sinus prolongs and does not heal with this treatment: then you know that in its depth there is a corruption: or that it makes an imprint in the bones, or in the other hard parts, or ligaments: then treat the fistula according to what has been said before
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the treatment of panaritium and nail-drawn, and the addition of incision of the finger, and section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XC
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritium is a swelling which arises under the nail of the thumb of the hand, or foot: and perhaps arises in the rest of the fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it prolongs, and is neglected in its treatment, and becomes inflamed, the swelling becomes hot: or it is corrupted, and emits pus, until it corrupts the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts the whole, and perhaps the corruption extends to the bone, until there is an offensive odor: and it makes the extremity of the finger wide, and makes its color dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you are treating it, with that which we said in the explanation, and the treatment does not confer cure: then it is necessary that you cut away with the knife the whole superfluity which remains from the nail
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the ulcer afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	The cautery is indeed useful for the ulcer above all.</start_of_turn>
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound, and the nail also is sound, and the addition of the nails overlaps the flesh inwards, and it begins to bite itself, and damages itself: then it is necessary to place a radium beneath the nail at the angle which bites the flesh, and push upwards: and cut away the flesh easily, and place over that which remains of the flesh from the burning and corrosive medicines until it is completely removed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however corruption has already occurred in the bone, then it is necessary to cut away the bone and extract it: for it will never heal while it remains corrupted in that bone.</start_of_turn
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	And if you see the corrosion and corruption advancing in the finger, then cut it off at one joint, as is appropriate in its remembrance.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however there occurs to the nail attrition or percussion: and it is accompanied by severe pain, then it is necessary to perform phlebotomy in the first instance.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with Spatumili cut in a transverse section from above downwards to the end.</start_of_turn>
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful, lest the cutting should reach the flesh which is under the nail, for you will thereby cause additional pain and swelling.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which rests the pain.</start_of_turn
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	A finger that is born with some man's hands is perhaps entirely fleshy; perhaps there are some bones in some of them; perhaps there is a nail in it. Some of them are born in the root of the joint, or their origin is in some node of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in some node of the finger, is not moved: and he who is born near the joint of the finger, perhaps is moved.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	He who is born of flesh, his section is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	As when you cut through his root with a broad spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	His origin in the root of the joint is difficult to cure.</start_of_turn>
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from cutting it.</start_of_turn>
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that case, where he is born at the end of the nodes of the finger, then it is necessary to cut through his flesh in a circular incision until you reach the bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then grasp the bone with one of your knives which fits into this.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Consolidation, however, which happens to fingers by means of pressure, happens frequently either from the nature of man himself, that is, because it is born with it, or from the consolidation of a wound, or from the burning of fire, and the like.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary to remove this consolidation until the finger returns to its natural shape.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then put between the bones some splints, or soaked rags in fat: so that they do not consolidate too quickly, and separate the bones: or put between the bones a thin sheet of lead, until the place is consolidated as it should be.</start_of_turn
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly, if consolidation occurs between some digits and the palm, then dry that consolidation, according to what is prepared and comes close to the figure of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	And concerning the incision of veins.
Caput XCII.	Chapter XCII
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are veins which are involved, large and full of melancholic humors that happen in many parts of the body: and most of the time their occurrences are in the legs, especially in the legs of those who are on the move and working, and in the porters.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	It is therefore necessary to administer an excision from the black bile somewhat forcefully alongside the evacuation.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then let a bloodletting be made from the patient easily with a basilisk.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these is in two ways with iron.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One is to cut them off, and extract the black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	The other is to elevate the vein, and extract all of it
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of them is in this way
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Embolize the limb in the first place with warm water, until the thick blood has dissolved
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the limb of the patient from the upper part of the thigh down to the lower part of the knee with a thread.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the vein in one place, or two, or three wide sections
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then lift it up, that is to say, extract the blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and from the top let the phlebotomies be made of the patient in the first place
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the limb until the quantity of blood which you have evacuated is equal to that which remains in the limb, and as much as the patient can tolerate of the pain
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	After the ligature is done: and command him to abstain from foods that generate black bile: and repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins are full, for that is harmful to the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of the part is to be done in this manner
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	The elevation of the limb is to be done when there are many hairs in it
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert the instrument into the bath: or bind it to his limb with warm water, until it turns red, and swell the veins: or perform a strong exercise, if there is no bath for him, until the limb is warmed up
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin along the line of the vein section: or at its end near the knee, or at its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with needles, and scrape the vein from all sides, until it appears to the sense: and it is at the appearance of this that the blood in it changes from red to black turning pale.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When the blood has gone out through the hole, the blood in it is like a cord of white thread.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert under it radium, until it is raised up and comes out of the skin: keep the blood suspended with a pledget of cotton wool
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other part nearby three digits.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein, until it appears to the sense
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then lift up the blood with the radium as you did before, and keep the blood suspended with another pledget like before
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry the other part, or several parts if necessary
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate and bind the last part near the heel
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract the thread above the navel.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	Then do this until you have extracted the thread from the section which is above the rest.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, it does not yield to being extracted, and hangs: then introduce a needle with a strong thread and ligate the thread, and extract it: or introduce it under that [Radium] and draw it out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Take heed, lest you cut [the vein].
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if you cut it, it becomes difficult to elevate the thread and it enters through that document into the belly
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have finally extracted the thread: then place upon the wound a soaked linen cloth dipped in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a twist which involves parts, and is not as we have said in accordance with the rule: then you must find upon the thread throughout the whole extent of the twist, and the place of the twist itself.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the thread with hooks, until you have extracted the thread whole: and take heed at your section above the thread that you do not cut the vein, or wound it: for it is difficult to elevate or extract it from there.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Be prudent in this matter.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	This is how the wound is closed when the vein is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The closing of the wound is like that of a blind man
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not curved like the other wounds, neither is it acute at the ends, as to cut the vein: and it has a large flexibility, gentle: for if it were slight, it would split the vein by its smoothness: or if it were too great, like this.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the vein of the thigh.
Caput XCIII.	On the extraction of the vein of the thigh.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs in warm regions, like Alizegi and Arabia, and in dry, warm regions, where little vegetation grows.</start_of_turn>
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	It is also found in other parts of the body besides the thighs.</start_of_turn
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Its formation is due to the decay of matter under the skin, like the bites of serpents and worms, and the worms that are generated between the skin and the flesh.</start_of_turn
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	The sign of the commencement of the extraction of this vein is inflammation in the thigh with swelling.</start_of_turn
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the area is to be desiccated.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein is extracted from the desiccated area, as if from the root of a plant or an animal.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When it appears from the extremity of the vein, then it is necessary to cover it with lead, whose weight is from a drachma to two drachmas and a node, and let the lead hang loose from the thigh.</start_of_turn
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Every time something comes out of the vein towards the exterior, cover it with lead and a node.</start_of_turn
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it prolongs for a long time, then cut off a part of it and cover the remainder.</start_of_turn
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	Do not cut through the root before all of it has come out.</start_of_turn
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut, it contracts and enters the flesh: and it causes an abscess, putrefaction in the place, and a bad wound.</start_of_turn
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Wherever it is necessary, it is necessary to extract [the stone] gradually, until it comes out completely from its last place without leaving anything behind in the body: and from this vein [the stone] comes out in some people at a distance of five palms and ten fingers.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And indeed it has come to my attention that it has gone out of the body for twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If, however, this should happen to you during the course of your treatment: then insert radium into the cavity of its [the stone], and perforate the cavity with a needle as long as the body, until it is evacuated completely from that material: and administer the decomposition of the place with physicians for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the aftercare of the wound.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And indeed this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many outlets, and comes out from every outlet branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for it in this way, as we said before, and as is required in this matter
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Of the cutting above the worms generated under the skin, and it is called Bovine Disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called in this land Bovine Disease: because it frequently happens to cows, and is a small worm which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	It runs throughout the body, ascending and descending: and is shown by its sensation during its walk from limb to limb, until it breaks through the skin at the place where it breaks and comes out
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the corruption of some humours
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As worms and serpents do, thus also lumbrici and ascarides within.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	They are like worms and serpents in their malice
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	When they enter the body and rise to the head, and reach their place, they often burst open there and come out, and destroy the eye: and thus it happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	Therefore, when you wish to cure them and extract them, it is not done except by their walking and their sensation
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore that you bind that which is above and that which is below with strong ligature
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over them, and extract them.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it has gone deep into the flesh, and you do not find it: then put a cautery with fire over the place until it dies
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than this is the corruption of its matter, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you see that it is approaching the head near the eye, then bind under it with strong eyebrow-lashes.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over them, and extract them
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the patient should abstain from food and drink, with physicians resolving the harmful humors of the body.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Of the section above the navel Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called Nakir in our land: and it is a pain which happens in some member, and then changes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	I too am affected by this, as I have mentioned to you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I have been called to a woman who is ill in some place
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	She has discovered her arm and sees swelling in the armpit of her arm
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	An hour later, she sees another swelling forming like a worm, going up to his shoulder more quickly than is possible: like silver that is running from one place to another
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore departed from that place, and it was fixed in the shoulder
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then, after an hour, it ran through the rest of the body, until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was returning all over her body, as I had seen
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I marvel at the speed of its change from limb to limb
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I too have never seen such an illness before in this way
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	I have indeed seen many people who suffer from pain that changes from limb to limb: but I have never seen anything like this before in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not believe this is possible, except that it is due to the moisture of the armpits: from which it appears that the pain is changing its location
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that this does not appear in delicate people and in bodies that are moist with sweat, where the armpits are hidden
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you see this happening, and the patient still feels pain: then if you see it in the eye, as we have said, grasp above and under quickly: and dry above, until the moisture is expelled: cauterize the place.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, you do not aid the eye itself with your hands: then care for it with the expulsion of bodily humors, and with that which ejects wind-poisons, and carminates it with foul pills and serapine pills, and the like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Of the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter XCVI.</start_of_turn>
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are varied according to their kinds, and according to the places from which they fall from the body.</start_of_turn>
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	There are indeed various kinds of arrows: for some have large cusps, others have small ones: some are concave, others are convex.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those which have three angles.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And there are those which have tongues.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And there are those which have stars.</start_of_turn
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	The latter are according to the parts in which they fall, is according to two modes.</start_of_turn
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or, the parts are from prominent parts which are concave, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and things of that sort.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When, therefore, it falls into any of these parts, and you see signs of death, which I will narrate to you afterwards, then it is necessary for you to extract the arrow from the part, for death follows its wound in various positions.</start_of_turn
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see these bad signs, and the arrow is not hidden deeply in the part, then extract it and care for the wound.</start_of_turn
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	Signs, therefore, of the brain when it is pierced by an arrow, and the bone is penetrated, and the substance above the brain is ejected, are: vomiting of saliva, spitting, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasm, and confusion of the intellect, and vomiting of bile.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood escapes from the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps the blood is shed, and the vessel is ruptured.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And from the wound's moistness white pus like putty escapes.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And from it blood-like moisture escapes like meat broth
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If these signs appear, then abstain from treatment and extract the instrument if it does not escape naturally.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the fracture when it lies in the chest are: that it is close to the left breast: and that it feels like it is fixed in something hard, not in something soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the fracture is of a movement like the pulse: and blood flows from the wound black
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following this are coldness of the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You know therefore that death approaches without doubt
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	The sign of the fracture when it wounds the lung is the escape of bloody foam from the wound: and the after-effects which follow the head, are swelling and change in the color of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And a great, high breath expires: and it craves cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the fracture lies in the breast, which is in the chest: then it is close to the loin: and there is a great sigh with pain and with gasping, with a tremor: and all the limbs of the arms are moving
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	If the fracture lies in the stomach, then perhaps blood escapes from the wound from some undigested food
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	If it lies in the abdomen, and is fixed in it: something like stool or bile or intestine which is broken escapes from the wound
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope in treating it, neither in extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow has fallen into the bladder, and urine is being excreted: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is more severe: then you know that it is mortal
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, neck, gut, tongue, auxiliary, ribs, spine, shoulder, hip, thigh, and leg, and similar parts of the body, are to be examined in accordance with various arrangements: when the arrow has not been found in an artery or nerve: and not that the arrow is venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	I tell you that I have seen many such arrows, which signify to you the futility of your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because I have seen the arrow go down into the pupil of his eye, into the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I extracted it from the other side, under the earlobe: and he was healed, and no wound remained in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had gone into his eye under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was hidden, and I did not find its tip except where it was stuck in its wood: and the arrow was a great one, like the arrows of the Turkish archers, with lead in it, in which there are no ears
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was healed of this, and no evil happened in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the gut of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabian arrow, and these are the ones that have ears
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Following this, between two ribs: and it was submerged in his gut
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I am prudent therefore with her, until I have extracted it: and the Christian is healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	Until I have extracted it, I am cautious with her: for it has perished within him.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed, and no change appeared in his condition concerning the wound, I extracted it: and he was healed, without any subsequent misfortune.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	I saw a man to whom an arrow had been shot in his back, and his wound was consolidated over his belly
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years, the arrow was extracted from the root of his thigh
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	I saw a woman to whom an arrow had been shot in her abdomen, and her wound was consolidated over her belly, and the arrow remained within her: and no change appeared in her condition from her natural operations
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	I saw another man to whom an arrow had been shot on his face: and his wound was consolidated, and the arrow remained, causing him little pain, just like many others
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	I extracted an arrow from the King’s nose, which had perished in the middle of his nose, and which had bent to the right side: and the arrow was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to treat him after the arrow wound for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the arrow wound closed tightly
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I questioned him carefully with subtle words, and he did not feel any pain: and even he himself recognized the puncture and the pain from his right side
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that it was nothing more than the puncture from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I placed the plaster upon the place where there was a virulent attraction, and digestion, trusting in me that the place would abate, and that a sign of an arrow would appear, as it did above: and it did not happen in the place where the arrow had followed.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I applied the plaster for many days in that place: and no accident happened, and the swelling subsided meanwhile: and he remained unable to extract it from that space until he felt an arrow one day enter his nose
Et narrauit mihi illud.	He told me about that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I placed upon that place a sharp and corrosive medicine for several days, until it opened: and when I tried to grasp it, I found a slight arrow which was adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound that sharp medicine again, until we saw the arrow clearly: and it passed out of itself within that space for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then when the swelling had subsided, and it was possible for me to introduce forceps into the wound, and to move it, it did not obey its exit: then I did not cease to dilate it, and to apply above it various means, until one day, when I applied it with pointed forceps, according as it had been customary at the end of a chapter, I was able to extract it from the wound
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	The physicians say that the cartilage of the nose does not recover
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it therefore, and the swelling subsided, and he recovered his health completely: and nothing was left of it
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you what was the case with the extraction of several arrows: so that you may know the rule and the signification of that which I have not mentioned
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions cannot be comprehended with mere narration: neither does this book comprehend them, nor does the skilled artisan compare them with few in comparison to many. He considers what is present alongside what is absent, and thereby discovers a new operation and a new instrument when external things of this art occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not depart from the members to which they are attached, except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by traction from the place from which they entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or in the opposite direction of the other part
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And whatever proceeds from where it entered, that is an arrow proceeding in a fleshy place: it is attracted and proceeds outwards
