Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not issue forth at the time when it fell: then it is necessary to remove it a few days later, because the flesh surrounding it has become corrupted: and it will be relieved of its attraction and its emission
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	In the same way, if it is fixed in bone and does not issue forth from it: then it must also be removed a few days later: and repeat with its attraction and movement every day, until it issues forth.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not issue forth from it after days: then it is necessary to perforate around the arrow in the very bone from all sides with a fine saw, until the arrow is loosened.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	And then draw out the arrow and remove it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If, however, the arrow is fixed in the head of a bone, and has passed through one of the brain cavities, and appears from the diseased side of some of those accidents which I mentioned: then abstain from the attraction of the arrow, and remove it, until it is equal to itself after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	If an arrow is retained within the bladder, then the urine does not prolong its course.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	If the arrow is not firmly fixed, except in bone, and does not penetrate as far as the bladder: it remains painful for some days, and nothing happens to it from these accidents. Then the origin of the arrow and its extraction must be sought out.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is firmly fixed, and does not yield to traction: then apply a compress around the arrow as I have told you before: then wait in place until it is healed
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If the arrow is hidden in the body and is not visible or palpable: then seek it out with your senses.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with some instruments that are suitable for the traction of the arrow.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you are unable to grasp it because of the constriction of the wound or because of the length of the arrow in the depth: and there is no bone, no nerve, or blood vessel there: then find above the wound until the wound is widened and the arrow can be easily extracted.</start_of_turn>
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	When these are held by the ears, then loosen the flesh firmly fixed in the bone from every side, by every means which you can think of, and draw out the arrow, if it is possible, without fracturing the ears or twisting them until they are relieved.</start_of_turn
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	When you are administering the extraction of the arrow from any place, then use the twist of your hand with forceps to all parts, until you make the arrow depart: and do the last thing cautiously, so that the arrow is not fractured and that its traction and extraction are easy.</start_of_turn
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you are unable to extract it within an hour, then leave it for a few days, until the surrounding matter putrefies.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then do it again: if an alien cause has produced a flux of blood, do what we said in the chapter concerning treatment. And guard your virtue from the incision of a vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	Do it diligently in every way that you can for the evacuation of the arrow: and let this be with ease, and tranquility, or slowly, and firmly, as I have told you
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	It is necessary that you should handle the arrow as you would a living thing, so that the patient remains according to the figure, as it was with the arrow itself in the case of the arrow in this matter.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For thus is the work of a craftsman.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible for you to do this, then do what you can from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which comes out from the opposite side, or which proceeds from that to the outside: or it makes a swelling at the extremity of the arrow towards the side which is close to the skin, and it goes out: dry it therefore above the wound, and let the incision be according to the quantity which they hold in their forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull out the arrow: it is itself easily expelled.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it is retained in the bone, then turn your hand according to the roundness, until you press the arrow into the bone, and expand it for itself: then pull it out
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then do it again, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow-shaft is in it, then push it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If indeed the shaft has broken, and you wish to administer a push: then introduce into the wound an instrument which is concave, so that its concavity may be introduced into the heel of the arrow: then push out the arrow with it
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If, however, the arrow is concave, then push it forward with the instrument entering into itself.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	If, however, the arrow is concave, then push it forward with the instrument entering into itself.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If, however, the arrow is toxic, then it is necessary to remove the entire flesh in which the poison is located: if this is possible.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for the wound as is appropriate for this case.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow has fallen into the chest, or the belly, or the side: and it is close to where you touch with your hand, and it is possible to dry over the wound: then dry, and burn at the incision of the vein, or nerve, and remove the arrow.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then bandage the wound, if necessary, and care for it until it has healed
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of forceps with which arrows are removed
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	There are two similar extremities like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not loosen the wound
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of forceps, large, small, and medium, according to the quantity of the arrow, and the thinness or thickness of the wound, and the tightness of the wound
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the pushing instrument for the concave arrow
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The form of the pushing instrument for the blunt arrow
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the handle like a radius, so that its entrance into the concave arrow is alleviated, and it is pushed with it
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The handle of this pushing instrument is concave like the beak of a bird: so as to alleviate the entrance of the arrow into itself and the pushing of it
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	On the Phlebotomy of Veins.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are to be phlebotomized, of which there are thirty in the body, are numerous.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	From these, there are six in the head: two pulse- veins which are behind the ears, which are called Herbae; two arteries which appear in two temporal regions; two veins which are in the two tear-ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes; a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi, which are in the neck
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are the veins which are called Algecherich
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	As for the veins which are phlebotomized in the arms, there are five veins in each arm
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, which is from the side of the armpit: and it names the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and is composed of the branches of the Basilica and the Cephalica: and it names the vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, which is situated in the domestic side: and is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it names the vein of the belly
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	The forearm is placed above the elbow: it is in this position from which the blood is drawn, and that which appears above the thumb is the mark of the puncture.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	The elbow is the joint between the annulus and the minimum: it has two rami.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	There are three bones in the leg and foot
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is under the thumb, which is bent from the side of the pinky
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second is the saphenous: its place is at the heel from the domestic side
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The third is the Achilles: its place is at the heel from the pinky side
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	There are three other bones like these in the leg
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	As for the drawing of blood from two veins after the olecranon
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The drawing of blood from these two veins which are behind the elbow is useful for ancient cataracts, headaches, haemorrhoids, and head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	The quality of the bled depends on what is narrated.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	It is necessary to loosen the head of the patient: one should tear the skin of the scalp over the two veins with rough cloth so that the blood flows well.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then let the patient grip with his neck, until two veins appear
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	Their places are behind the elbow in two depressed parts of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Look carefully with your finger and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there you will find the signs with the burn.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the lancet, which is called the Incidens
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it inside under the armpit to the chest, until the vein has reached the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then elevate your arm with the armpit and chest to the upper part, and make an incision in the armpit alongside the incision that has already been made.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be that of two joined fingers, or thereabouts: and let blood drain out as much as you wish
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tighten the vein with ligatures and let it go, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus has proceeded in the beginning of the book the incision of the veins, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Of the two veins in the armpit at their proper time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The two veins which are in two positions of phlebotomy are for the ancient half-head: for the jaw and the cheek: and for the course of superfluous blood towards the eyes
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is easy according to what I have told you
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Bind the patient's neck greatly, until two veins appear to the sense of sight: and let the pulse of them be shown under your finger
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then the signs with encasement.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then elevate the skin above the vein upwards with your index finger, and insert the phlebotomy incision underneath, and elevate the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And make an incision in the vein, as you did in the two other veins: and let blood run out according to the quantity that you need
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the ligature of the patient, and place your finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterwards, place above itself the foot and the calves, and tighten it from above the constriction strongly: and let it go when it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And thus follows the reminder of them, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Of the cutting of the front vein after the cephalic vein has been cut
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The dressing for the cutting of the front vein after the cephalic vein has been cut is for the old ailments of the face: and for headache, and redness: and for ulcers and wounds.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And concerning the quality of that cutting, that is what I shall tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	Let the patient sit with his neck bent forward until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	What is its shape like
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the pointed end which is at the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and pierce it above it with the pincer, or with something else in the same way: and let the blood run according to the quantity you desire
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then close the perforation of the patient, and tighten it up until it is healed
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with the wide phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	Indeed it is not right that the phlebotomy should be acute at the extremities, like the rest of the phlebotomies, but rather that it should be wide at the extremities
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the phlebotomy should be according to the passing of the blood: because the bone is near: and perhaps in that it will break the phlebotomy when it is slight
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the cutting of the veins in the two tear-ducts
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The ointment for two veins which are in two tear-ducts of two eyes, is for the eye from scabies and redness: and for swelling in the eye, and for the pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the vein-cutting of these is, that it should tighten the diseased neck with a slip of thread.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the vein-cutting is easy: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the vein-cutting be according to the transverse line for a little length, with a small needle, broad at the tip, for in that place there is no flesh.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the vein-cutting is too near the end, it may well break
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let there run out blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put over the head a bandage, and bind the head one night only, and heal the head
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	As for the vein-cutting of the nose, see to it that you do not cut too deeply, for there is a great vessel there.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are vein-cut for acute fever, and for excessive sweating, and for the pains of the face, such as a migraine, and redness which happens in the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the vein-cutting of these is, that it should tighten the diseased neck with a slip of thread
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take hold of his left nose with your left hand, and make the vein-cutting under the tip, long: and fix it in the middle of the nose itself, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because blood immediately flows out.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary to keep your last hand with the needle: and let blood flow out according to your need
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it once during the night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	It will restore itself quickly by itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	For the phlebotomy of veins consult Guidegi
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	But indeed Guidegi speaks of phlebotomy in cases of constriction of the chest, and of leprosy, and melancholy, and various diseases, and swellings and ulcers, and corrosions, that is, herpes of the bowels
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these is that it tightens the patient under his armpits with a bandage: and let the artificer stand above the head of the patient, and the patient sits on his seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then let the phlebotomy of the vein be as long as the phlebotomy is wide at its greatest point.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw from the blood as much as is necessary, or according to what you think is necessary for this purpose
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the bandage, and tighten two veins with the middle strap: so that the patient is not suffocated
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And leave it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound will heal by itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	For phlebotomy of veins consult Algeberich
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins according to Algeberich are suitable for phlebotomy because they confer to the cheek in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and bad ulcers, and lip fissures, and ulcers that are in the nose, and in the circumference of the eye
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these is that you make the patient sit before you: and tighten his neck with a bandage
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn the lip outwards and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side: and their demonstration is by the blackness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	Indeed: for round about their circumference are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	They must therefore be cut through with the knife which is going to be used for the incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If, however, you are in doubt and do not know which is which: then you must resort to the greater incision of both of them, and their demonstration.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And in the same way do two veins which are in the upper lip: and most commonly run with it: and cut through the two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	After the cephalic phlebotomy, draw out the vein under the tongue
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	For indeed the veins which are under the tongue are phlebotomized along with the cephalic vein: that is to say that the cephalic phlebotomy is for the affections which are in the gullet, and the pain of the uvula, and the pains of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that the patient sits between your hands facing the sun: and lift up his tongue, and look under the tongue on one side a vein, and on the other side a vein: and the colour of both is black
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Both are therefore to be cut through: and take care, lest you cut the last finger of your hand in the phlebotomy
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under these are arteries, and perhaps blood will flow out from them.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the cubit.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	For indeed three veins are phlebotomized in the cubit, which are in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	The bloodletting of the ears is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by using a wide lancet: or by using olive oil to soften the area: or by cauterization with a knife, which is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its method.</start_of_turn>
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is suitable for incision.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	There are both broad and narrow types according to the width of the veins and the tension of the ears. The form of the lancet for bloodletting is broad like a vessel.</start_of_turn
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	It is suitable for opening wide, full, protruding, apparent, large, and those veins which contain thick blood.</start_of_turn
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	This lancet is of smaller width and finer extremity.</start_of_turn
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for bleeding small veins which contain thin, yellow blood.</start_of_turn>
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	About bloodletting of the basilica.</start_of_turn>
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basilicae, which is one of these three veins of bloodletting, is considered to be an instrument.</start_of_turn
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the abscesses which are under the jaw and the throat, from that which follows the breast, and the belly: and it is suitable for the bloodletter with the lancet, so that he may cause bleeding and avoid excessive bleeding from that.</start_of_turn
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he is mistaken and adds too much to the puncture of the bloodletting, he will injure the artery, and there will be a flow of blood.</start_of_turn
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to bloodlet with the lancet alongside the puncture: but rather to cauterize with Alnesil.</start_of_turn
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the basilica does not appear visibly, then it is necessary that other individuals take charge of it, and change over to another, or ask someone else about it: or perform a phlebotomy at the elbow.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	If it is not visibly present, it is necessary that others take charge of it, and change over to another, or ask someone else about it: or perform a phlebotomy at the elbow.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If, however, you wish to perform a phlebotomy on yourself, then it is necessary before the constriction of the elbow, so that you can reach the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then the sign over the place with the finger, afterwards the arm, and dry the area with a concave section of the sponge with a phlebotomy of Alnesil, as we have said before.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware that the percussion does not fall on the space of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you go, when you tighten the ligature, the inflation in the place which you signed with your finger, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: you must therefore stop it immediately
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If blood is seen to flow from the phlebotomy, like the urine of a boy, and is pale red: then you know that it is from the artery
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore be careful, and place your finger on the long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If, however, blood is shed (much more than is shed), then tighten the arm, and let go of it: and beware lest the patient move: and be over the fear of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for a few days, until it is healed
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If, however, blood is not shed, and you feel it: and it is not there in your moment of need, then cut the artery if you see it.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	The extremities of it are drawn towards each other, and the blood is severed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take hold of the skin of the fistula, and find it: take hold of the middle one, and bind it above the place of the stricture below, with ligament and strings until the other day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	When the blood is severed, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for it with that which preceded the recollection of the blood from the place of the scattered blood: and the severance of the blood in this case is not difficult in many situations, because of the smallness of the wound, and the possibility of tying off the ligament from the arm
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the vein of the fistula
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The vein of the fistula is, however, suitable for phlebotomy, because it draws blood from the upper part of the head, and the lower part of the body: because it is composed of the branches of the basilica and the cephalic vein, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is suitable for the phlebotomist, that it should be above the fear of its phlebotomy, because under it is the nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds in the puncture of the phlebotomy, and finds the nerve, there will result in that a stupor, and the healing will be difficult, and perhaps will not heal at all
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears to be connected to sensation
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	And if it is hidden in some people, and is slight, and is not seen: then you must know that you must perform the phlebotomy as you would perform it on a vein, with Alnesil, and divide the nerve with your skill
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in length
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the Cephalic Bone.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomies of the Cephalic Bone are useful, because they draw blood from the head and convey it to the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	It is proper in this bone alone, if you will, to make phlebotomies, with an olive catheter or with a myrtle catheter: because it is safer for all the veins, because there is neither an artery nor a nerve under them
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Indeed, it agrees with you concerning the phlebotomy of the head only, that you may take only as much blood as is necessary at the first percussion, and that you inquire about a softer place: for it does not harm if it is not found at the first percussion, as it will return with subsequent phlebotomies.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Perhaps indeed in some people the after-effect does not appear when the first percussion is omitted, but it does not cause harm in any case
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the usefulness of Phlebotomy, and the precautions to be observed in its practice.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of Phlebotomy, and the accidents which arise from it, demand that you reflect upon them
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, therefore, you must know that Phlebotomy is not administered except for the preservation of health, and the maintenance of well-being, and the precautions against the occurrence of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that it should be performed in the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the Cephalic, and the Fusiform, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that it should be performed at the beginning of spring after the Lent, in summer, and autumn, and in winter after the feast of Pentecost, when there are signs of fullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let it be performed on the first or third day after three hours have elapsed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy, however, which is administered in ailments, has no fixed hour: but when opportunity and necessity demand it, at night or day, and at every hour, and at every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	It is not proper to perform phlebotomy on children until they are at least fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Phlebotomy should not be performed on a pregnant woman except in the fourth and seventh months.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Phlebotomy should not be performed on the elderly who have already passed their sixtieth year
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When, however, anyone wishes to perform phlebotomy for any reason: it is necessary to give the patient a laxative before phlebotomy when there is much stool remaining in the intestines: so that they do not draw out harmful putrefying matter to the principal parts during phlebotomy
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Phlebotomy should not be performed on a patient who is suffering from nausea, or who is intoxicated with alcohol or from overeating until these symptoms have subsided from the body
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither on a patient suffering from hydrophobia.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	Phlebotomy should not be repeated immediately after a bout of vomiting, diarrhea, flux of urine, prolapse of the bowels, labor, exercise, joy, or indigestion of food
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the temperament of the humors before doing this, if the blood is thick with food and fat, and with physicians: if possible do it to him
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him take a bath, if it does not oppose it: or let him perform some exercise, in order to make the blood finer
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the phlebotomy in his chest, around the third of the day, as we have said: and strive that he evacuate his chest from all bad things: such as envy, wrath, fear: and from all physical things, such as labor, suffering, excess, and similar things
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And the seeds of it make present all things with which the habit of men runs along from aroma, and odor, and delight and the like in quantity as it is possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	And sit the phlebotomist above the elbow, which is higher than the elbow of the phlebotomist: then he shall extract his arm and wipe it with his hand twice or thrice.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he shall bind the ligament with strips and twist it twice.</start_of_turn
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the binding be temperate, for when the binding is unequal, or through excess in the binding, then it hinders the course of the blood: or in softening, then also it hinders the course of the blood.</start_of_turn
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the binding let him wipe the phlebotomist's hand together until the veins become filled and the patient feels it.</start_of_turn
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist shall remove the phlebotom from the patient with a little oil, as he did at the beginning.</start_of_turn
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he shall place his finger of his left hand on the said vein under the place where the phlebotomy was made, slightly: so that it does not escape the blood, and cause pain.</start_of_turn
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For from veins is more like a fleeing cord concerning the phlebotomy: and from that which is full of blood: and when you place the phlebotomy on it, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and crushes the phlebotomist, and does not open the vein: and if it does open, it is tight: because of this therefore it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm, and attentive in all these things.</start_of_turn
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	And let him remove the phlebotomy.</start_of_turn
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If, therefore, an opening has occurred from a vein, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	If not, then repeat the process with another vein below or above the same place somewhat, or with a suture: if the place does not recover.</start_of_turn>
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it swells, or if the patient becomes faint, then release him on the first or second day: and do not tighten the ligament.</start_of_turn>
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps the swelling will subside on its own.</start_of_turn
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither introduce a poultice.</start_of_turn
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.</start_of_turn>
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or if blood flows too slowly: and take care that it does not escape from the blood more than is necessary: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to the direction of the vein, and add a little in the process.</start_of_turn
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it with a suture before the place has recovered, for the place is often swollen in many men after an operation.</start_of_turn
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you have already applied some of it to the swelling, then do not repeat it above all, for it does not excuse you from doing something else.</start_of_turn
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something of the fat of olive oil on it: because it softens the course of the blood.</start_of_turn
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than pure oil, and than any other oil.</start_of_turn
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And in the same way administer the fat of olive oil in all your phlebotomies, which you perform against the flow of blood: and make it become like tyriaca alfarach, and sagebrush, when you place one of them on the place.</start_of_turn
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood becomes subtle and resolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	When blood is thick, it becomes subtle and resolves
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	When blood is withdrawn from a vein, it must be completed by the addition of its complement or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something dark or green remains in the place after a day, or if there is swelling, it does not harm to apply something of aloe or myrrh to it: or something of the juice of mint, which is like camomile.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And often indeed do swellings and abscesses occur at phlebotomy in the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand over it [the phlebotomy site], and if you feel softness under your compression, then the swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore put something on it as we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster of it with something which has styptic properties, so that the place is enclosed
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw out of every man from blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the redness of the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then send it away until it turns red: and in the same way if you see it thick, then send it away until it becomes subtle: and in the same way if it is acute, until the sharpness is gone
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	He who is full, strong, and averse to bloodletting should perform it cautiously and with a wide incision; and in him who is bilious, it should be done in the reverse order of that.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	He who is full, strong, and averse to bloodletting should perform it cautiously and with a wide incision; and better is it when the incision is transverse than when it is punctured
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	He who is full, strong, and averse to bloodletting should perform it cautiously and with a wide incision; and better is it when the incision is transverse than when it is punctured from end to end.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	He who has suffered from swelling at the phlebotomy should be given before it a spoonful of bread soaked in pomegranate juice: or saffron, if he is feverish: and let him extract from him in three or four veins.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	If his complexion is cold, then he should be given before the bloodletting a spoonful of bread soaked in vinegar or in honey syrup flavored with spices, or in scented syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If there is fainting during bloodletting, and the cause of it is excessive bleeding: then it is necessary to give him in the drink water of meat, and a mild scented syrup: and mix with it aromatic herbs, and support his chest with these things: and do all the things which we mentioned in the chapter on fainting from evacuation
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to do his arm and solve his blood by means of evacuation: must know that the more blood he evacuates, and the more bilious he is, the more slowly he will solve his blood by the quantity of bile in the continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to do his arm and solve his blood by means of evacuation, and his body is strong: then let him do it after seven hours, or nine from his first bloodletting
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of the part which it inclines: it must be done on the second or third day
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And what is the quality of the phlebotomy, that it may admit the sick man's hand into warm water, until the bubble ruptures, and a foam appears?
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is bound over itself with a slight median constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the phlebotomy is done gradually across, not lengthwise, nor along: and let the opening be wide, and your phlebotomy be as high as the phlebotomy over the wound of the hand nearby
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the bloodletting is forbidden, then do it again with the hand in warm water, and let the blood run in the water, until you achieve your purpose
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the summer days, then you may excuse yourself from the repetition of the hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And most of all, the course of the blood in warm water is put in winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this foam is more useful than all the foams, because there is no pulsating vein under it, neither nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand of Salvatella is beneficial for liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And what is the quality of this phlebotomy, that you bind the hand with the ligament, or your hand itself, after you have introduced it into the warm water, until the foam inflates and it is perceptible to the sense of cold.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then let the phlebotomy be done across
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein completely, it will not harm it in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful not to move your hand with the phlebotomy
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under this, there are the nerves of the fingers denuded of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then again, move the hand to the warm water, and let the blood run out of it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	If you do not move the hand into the warm water, the blood will coagulate at the mouth of the vein, and will be prohibited from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	Once you have drawn out the quantity of blood necessary, then put upon the vein oil and salt: so that it does not solidify too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	It is also necessary to do this with every strict limb.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The true cause of the disease of the spleen is: because it is connected to the diseases of the liver. And do the same in the phlebotomy of this as you did in the second, equally
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	However, the cause of the disease of the veins is for the diseases which are in the lower part of the body, such as the diseases of the uterus, and retention of the menses, and weakness of the kidneys, and ulcers of the buttocks and thighs of an old person, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	The quality of this phlebotomy is that it introduces the patient's foot into the warm water: and makes over it friction, until the veins become empty: and binds above the junction of the foot with a bandage
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	The veins are in the heel, appearing under the thumb: and are torn from it in the face of the foot of many toes
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore better in a wider limb, or in the heel in its collection: because it is better and safer
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you do the phlebotomy on the face of the foot, then you will cause damage to the nerves which are under it over the face of the foot
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And put your phlebotomy through from side to side, as if you wished to cut through it: and make the phlebotomy neat.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the flow of blood is prohibited, then repeat the foot in hot water: and hold back the blood from flowing outwards until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the vein has slipped from the first incision, then repeat the incision above the other: for the place is safe, and not from there does malice arise, when you cause it to descend from nerves, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And in like manner with the other foot's vein, equally.</start_of_turn>
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins of the sciatic nerve are located, as we have said, beside the heel on the outside.</start_of_turn>
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the sign of its phlebotomy is for relief of swelling, when it is because of cold blood.</start_of_turn
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is that it should be performed with a cold pack, and be speedy: and tighten the limb from the side of the swelling up to the ankle four fingers, with a fine long probe: it should not be seen except for this.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then the phlebotomy is done according to whatever means is possible to you, or according to the passage: and it is better either to cut the vein with a knife, or to divide it by section.</start_of_turn>
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place of the vein is safe, and it is often hidden in many people.</start_of_turn
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it, and it does not appear at all: then phlebotomy take some branch of it, and that is the one which appears in the back of the foot, and below the ankle: and cause the blood to flow outwards as much as you will.</start_of_turn
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tightening, and place over the place of the phlebotomy some skin, and tighten the limb.</start_of_turn
Uelociter enim sanatur.	Healing is swift.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Concerning the action of the wind, and the quality of its influence.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XCIII.</start_of_turn>
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Winds are generated by the movement of the body [of air], from the air, and from within.</start_of_turn>
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the action of the wind is performed in two ways.</start_of_turn
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	One is through scarification and the extraction of blood; the other is the action of the wind without scarification.</start_of_turn
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this action of the wind which is without scarification is performed in two ways.</start_of_turn
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or else with fire.</start_of_turn
Aut est absque igne.	Or without fire.</start_of_turn
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And those winds which are administered with scarification and the extraction of blood are fourteen in number concerning the body.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of these, one is the Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is the most remote of the head: and Alkehel, which is in the middle of the neck: and the winds of Alhagdahim, which are two layers of the neck from two parts together: and the wind of menti, which is under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth: and the winds of the two spatulae: and the wind of Alachosos which is over the end of the tail: and the winds of the two focilia, which are in the middle of the two arms: and the winds of the two crura: and the winds of the two heels.</start_of_turn
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed the action of the wind does not draw blood from the veins that are small and scattered throughout the flesh, and because of this it does not cause the loss of blood as is the case with phlebotomy.</start_of_turn
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither should the application of the cautery be administered either with fire or without fire in any ailment which arises from obstruction, until the entire body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	In the event that the need arises for cautery in an ailment, either because of custom or by necessity, we shall administer it at the beginning, middle, and end of the month, and at any other time as required.</start_of_turn>
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For, when men multiply in their blood, until they require extraction by cautery, they find swelling in their head and softening.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from this is known the cause of repletion and redness in the face, head, and neck.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from this is known the cause of itching in the face, forehead, temples, and dimness of vision.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from this is known the place where cautery is to be applied.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from this is known laughter that multiplies.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from this is known the taste of blood in the mouth: either the tongue is sprouted and blood is spat out.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from this is known sleep that multiplies.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from this is known vomiting in sleep of blood, redness, and intercostal haematoma, which are similar to these.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see any of these things, and especially if it is in the middle of the month: we immediately order cautery, after two or three hours have passed.</start_of_turn
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The application of the cautery at night is not useful: for it itself causes swelling in the head and effluvium of blood to the eyes.</start_of_turn
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	After the evacuation of the entire body, it is necessary at the navel.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	This is the umbilical region.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to touch those who are pale in complexion or have a discharge from the eyes.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For they are in great danger.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	Neither should they be used for the elderly, in whom there is cold in the head.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever persists in this treatment becomes subject to the blame.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	Therefore it is necessary to order the assistant to place his hand on the lower parts with the open palm towards the feet, fearing lest blame should arise from this action
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The application of vinegar or alum is the place of the phlebotomy of the veins of the buttock and the veins of the groin, and because of this it brings about asthma, constriction of the chest, swelling of the instruments, sneezing, and distension of the belly
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary to apply vinegar or alum with force from above downwards, because if it is applied downwards, it produces stiffness in the heart and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The application of vinegar or alum brings about pain in the head, swelling of the temples, headache, perforation and toothache: it is the place of the phlebotomy of the groin.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Therefore it is necessary to order the assistant not to touch the hand to the wound: that it does not cut the artery and cause the flow of blood to be obstructed
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The application of vinegar under the chin brings about nausea in the mouth, corruption of the gums, and similar ailments that are in the mouth: it is the place of the phlebotomy of the external jugular veins, which are in the two angles of the jaw
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The blowing of the wind towards the spatulas stirs up the alchafacham, which is produced from the reflection and the heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The blowing of the wind towards the inner parts of two cavities stirs up the phlebotomy of veins of the groin, of the belly, and of the heel, and of the head: because that very attraction attracts blood from all those small veins which are in the flesh: and those veins attract the small veins from other large veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary, that the master of the wind should not proceed too much in the incision: because the place is denuded of flesh, and under that are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The wind which is blown over the cushions stirs up hemorrhoids of the ass, and the lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary, that the master of the wind should make the wind great and dry: because the place requires strong suction, and perhaps the subtle winds will be broken: and it will be made with great incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The winds of the crurium diminish visibly: because they attract blood from the whole body, and cause ancient pains in the buttocks, and in the belly, and in the testicles: they cause menstruation, and cause swelling, and madness: and they stand in the place of the phlebotomy of the two saphenae, and of the alhorcobeni
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	But they weaken the body very much, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the winds of the alhorcobeni are near to the winds of the two crurium.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the wind is that you place the greater wind in the first place, and you temper the suction: and do not prolong the position of the wind, but place the hand quickly, and move the hand quickly, so that the humors come to the place at the same time: and do not stop doing this and continuing, until the ideas reach the place where it is red and swollen, and where there appears red blood: then indeed make the incision, and repeat the suction gradually
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Consider then the arrangement of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	Therefore, he who is a man of flesh and blood, rare of hair, must make an incision once only, not more: that he may not wound the place.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the wind-bladder, that it should increase the incision, and that it should be made shallow: and temper the suction in its facility, speed, and movement of its air.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickness in the blood, then it is necessary, that he make an incision twice.
